5.text: Well, thank you everyone for welcoming me.

8.text: I feel a bit jet-lagged, so I said no PowerPoint today.

13.text: I wanted to have a conversation and we've spent some time

16.text: talking about this class and about what you're learning and

20.text: about the center and so I'm really excited to be here.

22.text: I'm really excited to talk about how I started my company.

27.text: So that's like a very long time and I think it's

30.text: also because it's been a really long time.

32.text: So I want to talk about how I started.

35.text: I started my company back in 1996 and so it feels very ancient.

41.text: The tools I had available to me to do that and to start are very

46.text: different than what I think young entrepreneurs have today.

49.text: And so I want to talk a bit about how I started and focus on

53.text: the work we do at the agency and then what we do now.

56.text: And I hope to save kind of some significant time to have Q&A

60.text: and to engage with you and answer your questions.

63.text: So let me start off with how I started Buzz.

66.text: So I never ever thought I would be an entrepreneur.

69.text: In 1996 that was not a word that was really kind of known to me.

75.text: I always thought I would be a beauty editor.

77.text: So I was very focused on fashion and beauty and I wanted to be

81.text: an editor at primarily a teen girl magazine kind of like 17.

86.text: And so, at 16, I applied for a job with the newspaper for Girls out

91.text: of New York City called The New Girl Times and at the Times I primarily

96.text: wrote product reviews focused on - my first column ever was for a company

101.text: called High Intensity that made very cool jewelry.

104.text: And I found during that process of reviews that when I would

107.text: submit the column back to whoever gave me a product,

111.text: they would always say if I keep sending you

113.text: a product will you tell me what you think?

115.text: And at 16, I thought that was the coolest thing ever.

117.text: I thought there that there were tens of companies

118.text: who would send me products if I just told them what

120.text: I thought and so I thought that was the gig.

123.text: I didn't think it was a way to make money.

125.text: It was something I became really passionate about and even at 34,

129.text: I still - I'm so passionate about trends,

131.text: about new things, about whether it's reading about

134.text: a new destination in Conde Nast Traveller,

136.text: it's something that still fuels me today;

138.text: the idea that there are so many new products to try, so little time.

143.text: So back in '96, I remember a lot of PR-type people who were

150.text: my 'clients' and I started getting phone calls like

153.text: "I have a friend, she works on this brand.

156.text: You'd be really cool to talk to."

157.text: And I didn't really understand what the conversation would be.

160.text: I was literally a suburban teenage girl and I should - I guess -

165.text: go back and say I am the oldest of six children and so the

169.text: eight of us where I was kind of the odd kid doing this interesting

172.text: thing and since all of my siblings have really interesting

176.text: careers and do really interesting things,

177.text: but at the time it was something very different and very new and so

180.text: my parents were like why is UPS - why are UPS and Fedex here everyday?

184.text: So no one really got what was going on.

186.text: I didn't really get what was going on.

188.text: But it was happening really quickly and so by the time I was 17,

194.text: again, I use that word very loosely because I hadn't yet had that

198.text: moment where I realized I could make money doing what I was doing.

202.text: And so I started to recruit my friends and say

205.text: if I gave you guys some of these products,

207.text: can we all review them and I will tally our scores and

210.text: I will send this little report back to our client and so that

215.text: works for a while and then my friends would say well,

218.text: I have a cousin in Texas and she would love to be one of the your

221.text: trend spotters and again think about the time we're talking about.

225.text: I said, well, how would I communicate with her?

227.text: I had just gotten an AOL email address at 16.

231.text: So the idea of technology and connectivity wasn't

235.text: something that was yet really relevant,

239.text: And the way to communicate, the way our network communicates today,

243.text: didn't really make sense at that time.

245.text: So continued pretty small until I got to college

250.text: and as a freshman in college I had two real important

253.text: things that happened at the same time.

255.text: First, I took my intro to business course at Hood College;

258.text: I went to a womens' school, Hood College in Frederick, Maryland.

262.text: And I took an intro to business with the Head of the Department

264.text: and at the same time I was working on one of these reports for

268.text: a fashion company and my client at the time called and she said

272.text: I'm going to tell you something really important.

275.text: I reviewed it with my team and yours is 10 times

278.text: better than a report we paid $25,000 for.

282.text: it's called market research and that's all

284.text: I'm going to tell you, go figure it out.

286.text: And so during office hours I went into Dr. Jose's office,

289.text: I said here is what I've been doing for the last 2.5 years.

293.text: And she took some time and kind of just stared at me for a while and

296.text: then she said I want you to take an independent study with me next

299.text: semester and let's see if we can't make this a real business.

301.text: And so I was really fortunate at that

304.text: time to - like I always tell Dr. Jose,

307.text: I got beat up for 13 weeks in a row into

310.text: creating a business and marketing plan,

312.text: but I still use those plans today.

316.text: because when I was in college at that time,

317.text: so I think '97 to probably spring of '98,

321.text: it was right around that like .com

324.text: boom and so when Dr. Jose and I talked,

327.text: she said I don't want you to get caught up in what

330.text: at that point seemed to be a kind of trend.

332.text: She was like I want you to build a business that's a solid

335.text: business and if there is a digital component that's great,

337.text: but you've got to build a solid business and there

340.text: were - I mean I try - to help you understand what was

342.text: happening at this time in the Internet,

346.text: that were raising $50 million and then

348.text: went bust a couple months later.

350.text: So it was very different than I think kind of the builder moment,

354.text: that's happening now and in a little bit I will

356.text: get into some of the trends we're studying.

361.text: I need to build this solid business and I was really fortunate

364.text: that when I needed to understand statistics I could go and

367.text: talk to a professor and if I needed to understand how psychology

371.text: and sociology played into my business,

373.text: there were people that were available for me to talk to.

376.text: So of course I am a big advocate of building

378.text: businesses while you are in school.

381.text: I think that I always say my education definitely worked for me.

385.text: And it was really important for me to actively

388.text: be a student and also build this business,

391.text: and so I can - I worked with Dr. Jose and realized okay,

396.text: I have services, now I can make money and started working

400.text: really hard at recruiting clients and by the end of my

404.text: college career I was working with Verizon Wireless.

407.text: I remember spring of my senior year doing a research project for them

410.text: and flying to California and back to school for class and

413.text: I spent my junior year instead of staying abroad, I studied away.

418.text: which I really found to be kind of the Mecca for marketing

421.text: and so at 22 I'd had a lot of experience.

424.text: At this point, six years of running this business and I still

427.text: thought maybe this was just a really interesting hobby.

431.text: I didn't actually think this was going to be my

434.text: career for as long this has been my career.

436.text: And so I still remember the conversation

438.text: with my advisor when I said oh,

440.text: I had just watched legally blonde - I was just talking about this last

444.text: week in another conference and thought I should go to law school.

446.text: I don't know people who like fashion and

448.text: beauty go to law school, I don't know.

449.text: I remember her just saying yes,

451.text: you could go to law school because you're a very good student.

454.text: And not knowing that this is what I wanted to do,

457.text: and I had been getting some media and I thought that

460.text: the media was focused on my story of being this interesting

468.text: at 21, I didn't think that was the way to build a business;

472.text: so focused on one person, one story.

474.text: And I also didn't think it was the right story.

477.text: I didn't think it was the right message because at some point

479.text: you have to grow up and you have to be respected as a research

482.text: company or whatever is that we were becoming not there is this

486.text: school girl that does this cool stuff with the product;

488.text: I felt like there was a timeline on that.

491.text: And so I said to my advisor,

493.text: we really talked, spent quite a bit of time in different

496.text: sessions talking about should I go to law school,

497.text: should I do vastly different things,

501.text: should I go into the field and just apply for a job.

504.text: And I remember my girl friends senior year reading like this

508.text: book on quarter life crisis and it was really funny.

511.text: They were like oh, you of course don't need to read this book.

513.text: I'm like: I probably have the biggest crisis here of everybody.

517.text: But I decided, I said to my advisor at the time,

520.text: I said here is what I'm going to do.

521.text: I think that - when I graduated,

524.text: it was spring 2002, and illegal downloading had become

528.text: a major issue or it was becoming kind of thing.

530.text: You know, it was the Shawn Fanning movement and that sort of thing.

534.text: And during the spring of my senior year,

537.text: I spoke at a music industry conference.

539.text: It was a very interesting conference because there

542.text: were three other presenters from really,

544.text: really big research institutions and they were saying

547.text: things to the audience who you can imagine,

550.text: were people who were quite concerned about illegal downloading and

554.text: they were saying things like: it's not going to be an issue,

557.text: only 17% of people illegally download music.

561.text: And then I get up, this senior in college

564.text: who has a research panel at that time,

567.text: I should back up and say our network grew to 9,000 people

570.text: solely because CosmoGirl Magazine wrote two sentences

573.text: about what I was doing and I got 15,000 applications

576.text: from people all over the world who wanted to be

578.text: buzzSpotters and so we really created this great network.

582.text: And we had done research and found

584.text: of the 500 people that we surveyed,

586.text: that 99% of them had illegally downloaded

590.text: And so obviously we were presenting two very,

594.text: very different sets of data and so I kind of was disheartened,

599.text: I was cut out of an article and billboard and I thought okay,

602.text: well that is what it is.

604.text: And so back to that conversation with Dr. Weinberg,

608.text: I said, you know what I want to do,

609.text: I want to - I have always wanted to be a liaison

611.text: between consumers and people who target them.

614.text: And at the time it was teens and then as I grew

617.text: older it was the young adults and now I'm 34,

620.text: so we jut say consumers and people who market to them.

623.text: And I said well, I want to talk about things

626.text: that other people don't want to talk about.

628.text: And I don't have any skin in the game to necessarily

631.text: need to go one direction or prove one thing.

632.text: I'm really curious as to why consumers do what they do and what

636.text: their interests are and so presenting that research was to say,

640.text: you might be right, maybe only 17%

644.text: I just have a belief that the 99% that are in this demographic

648.text: I'm dealing with have a really huge impact.

651.text: And, obviously we know now that that did have

654.text: an incredible impact on that business.

655.text: I think still today it is impacting the music

658.text: business and how that business is shaped now.

661.text: And so, yes, that's always my example of the power of Millennials

664.text: and the power of consumers when they decide

667.text: that something is or is not working for them.

669.text: And so, I decided I was going to try that out for a year.

673.text: I opened an office in New York City and I work there.

676.text: I lived in South Jersey and I still live in South Jersey today,

679.text: and so did that for three or four years.

681.text: And I guess that most interesting thing that happened during

685.text: that time was I was featured in a cover story for O Magazine.

690.text: And so at 25, having that Oprah stamp

694.text: of approval on my career was huge.

696.text: I didn't think it would be.

697.text: Not that I didn't think the Oprah brand was huge;

700.text: I just didn't think anybody cared about a

702.text: kid who was doing research in New Jersey.

704.text: I just didn't think that was a story that would resonate with people and

707.text: obviously if you're lucky enough to be touched by the Oprah brand,

711.text: it does turn to gold if you're doing something good.

714.text: And so, it was great for us and I still remember clients

717.text: coming into the office like with my actual page from

720.text: the Magazine kind of like we saw this and so,

723.text: that was great for our agency and I think we kind of - again other

728.text: profiles and 30 under 30 and all kinds of awards which for me

733.text: and I think you'd understand if you're an entrepreneur,

735.text: you have to be fascinated by your work and passionate about

738.text: it and the other stuff is just stuff that happens.

741.text: It's not something you pause - and I think my mom,

744.text: I realized recently has a clip book of all of my different media,

748.text: but for me it was just this is another day and it's

751.text: another day that I get to do something that I love.

753.text: And so, we continued to grow the network,

756.text: continued with our research and then the economy took a turn,

760.text: which was interesting because what happened

765.text: So we got into influence of marketing, again, by accident.

769.text: I had a client call and say the girls I talk to about beauty

773.text: were having some issues launching a product at Sephora,

776.text: do you think we could engage them in influencer?

781.text: so I don't think - it was right around the time BuzzAgent was

785.text: coming along and I thought I don't know that we're that.

788.text: I've always really wanted that line of consumers being able to openly

793.text: and honestly express their opinions to brands and that was a really-and

796.text: still is-a very core value of our company and very important to me.

800.text: So that means if I have to say something that's not great,

803.text: that that has to be okay.

804.text: And that also is a big reason why I don't have a team of 50,

809.text: 60, 70 people because sometimes I do have to make decisions that

812.text: I think are a little more ethically driven for our business.

815.text: And so at that time I wasn't sure it would work and we

819.text: tried influencer and it worked really, really well.

822.text: And so we incorporated that into our services

825.text: and so when the economy took a turn,

827.text: it was a lot of traditional things that were getting

830.text: cut and people were reinvesting into the type of work

832.text: we do and so we have over the last 18 years,

837.text: worked with 135 companies and I guess some highlights for

841.text: me would be companies like American Eagle Outfitters,

847.text: and so we've gotten to touch some really big brands

850.text: and I've learned so much from our clients.

853.text: And I'd say personally for me,

856.text: one of the more fun accomplishments - a lot

858.text: of people talk about my business book,

860.text: but not so much about my children series.

862.text: So I write a series for 7 to 12 year old girls.

865.text: It's published by HarperCollins Children's Books,

869.text: And it's really focused on a girl I think is kind of like

872.text: a modern Ramona and I've written five books in the series.

877.text: So it's a really fun - I feel like it's my fun passion project.

882.text: I'm working on another series right now.

885.text: It's all about a girl who can't tell a lie and what happens

887.text: in middle school and so writing and creating McKenzie

892.text: and creating a character that is really beloved by girls

895.text: has been an interesting experience for me,

897.text: especially as a researcher, because through McKenzie,

900.text: through her life, I get to see girls react to her and really

904.text: get to understand kind of what's going on in the life of a 12-year-old

907.text: girl and that was something really interesting.

909.text: And then I guess as a final comment before

912.text: I open it up to your questions.

914.text: Two years ago, I was elected to

918.text: the United Nations Foundations Global Entrepreneurs Council.

920.text: And so we are charged with bringing innovative ideas to the UN.

925.text: And if I weren't working for myself,

928.text: I'd absolutely love to work for the UN and so

931.text: it's been a really incredible experience.

933.text: That's why I'm actually in San Francisco now.

936.text: it's our last, and so it's just been an unbelievable

940.text: experience for me for the last two years,

942.text: and earlier this year I got to spend some time in Uganda.

945.text: I got to visit a refugee settlement and meet entrepreneurs.

950.text: And when I think about what entrepreneurship means to me now at 34,

954.text: a bit more established and kind of what your opportunity is.

957.text: When I started out, there were not a lot of tools

960.text: and there weren't a lot of people that could help

964.text: other people rationalize what I was doing.

966.text: You guys live in a world where everybody

970.text: everybody knows what it means to be an entrepreneur

977.text: I was that girl doing that weird thing and people were

979.text: saying to my parents your daughter is so smart,

981.text: why isn't she a lawyer or a doctor?

983.text: They just didn't get it and so I'm now members of many different associations

989.text: that didn't exist when I started and so I think that the entrepreneurial

993.text: spirit and especially what I got to see in Uganda has really made me

997.text: an even bigger champion of entrepreneurship.

1001.text: Seeing innovation that can drive and create business opportunities

1006.text: in Uganda and meeting female entrepreneurs who are creating

1011.text: an amazing life for their children that are able to send

1014.text: their children to private schools just because they're entrepreneurs

1018.text: and they've simple businesses, selling soap, having farms,

1022.text: is something that was really interesting to see.

1025.text: And so, I guess at this point, I'd love to open-up for questions.

1028.text: We can talk about my work, we can talk about trends that I'm seeing;

1035.text: I know for a second you touched on like almost like an

1038.text: ethical quandary in your business from time to time.

1040.text: I was wondering if you could just elaborate on that.

1045.text: He was talking about really the ethics

1047.text: involved in what I do everyday.

1049.text: And I think that marketing is an interesting

1055.text: area when you talk about that, right.

1057.text: It's the images that we create, the messages that we send.

1060.text: I think that there was a time where I talked to my clients

1065.text: about kind of a one way funnel where we push things out

1068.text: to consumers and imagine when I was a teenager,

1073.text: I will use myself as an example,

1074.text: I feel like Gap dictated my whole life.

1076.text: It's like when their fall campaign came out,

1079.text: that's who I was, that is what I was going to be.

1082.text: And if I wanted a really specific shoe, there was no online shopping.

1087.text: I went to a mall that dictated what

1089.text: I had access to and that was that.

1092.text: If I was this suburban Jersey girl,

1093.text: this is what I could have access to.

1096.text: And I'm sure we remember those times where our friends

1098.text: would travel to the West coast and would get something

1100.text: there that we couldn't get at home.

1101.text: And so I think it created this funnel where marketers

1105.text: could project onto consumers what was cool.

1111.text: I think there was a particular one I saw call

1114.text: the Merchants of Cool where Sprite actually said,

1116.text: we project onto you the image of who we want you to be.

1120.text: And that for me was definitely a bit of an ethical dilemma

1123.text: and I think I was coming about in a time where technology has

1128.text: created this interesting democracy where consumers can,

1133.text: I feel, have the power and can dictate things to brands.

1137.text: Gap changed its logo, consumers didn't like it,

1140.text: they changed it back to the old one.

1141.text: That would never happen in my opinion 20 years ago.

1144.text: I think your ability to shop online and to make those

1148.text: types of decisions totally changes the playing field.

1153.text: It's if I don't like this, I won't do it.

1155.text: If I don't want to buy a car, I can use Uber now.

1159.text: If I want to be a conscious consumer, there are ways I can do that.

1161.text: And so I think that for me,

1165.text: I have always erred on the side of just working with brands that

1168.text: I really like and brands whose products I'm passionate about.

1173.text: And it's hard, because there are some - for me,

1177.text: can I say, I always feel passionate about Dell,

1183.text: I may not have - the products I got to work on were

1186.text: amazing products for people who need PCs.

1188.text: But what I was really passionate about was Michael Dell's

1192.text: entrepreneurial spirit and that he is really a true entrepreneur

1196.text: who is fascinated by new things and creating new things and

1200.text: so that for me was someone I could get behind.

1202.text: And I think that in general,

1205.text: I would tell you 90% of the people I've worked with have really

1208.text: wanted to connect with this consumer and the people who wanted

1212.text: to dictate to them weren't people that would work with my system

1215.text: anyway because the consumer and that research and data,

1219.text: we have a process we call connect-brand-impact-understand and the first

1223.text: step in that process is bringing in the voice of the consumer.

1226.text: So you can imagine if you're a marketer that you already have

1228.text: your plans and you just want me to verify what you're saying,

1231.text: we probably wouldn't the best match.

1233.text: So I think that earlier in my career it was something that probably

1237.text: came up a lot more where now I feel like it's the reverse for brands

1241.text: who are understanding that you dictate what's going to happen and

1243.text: they're just trying to figure out where they fit.

1248.text: What methods do you use or like where do you look

1250.text: to spot trends and what trends are going on today?

1254.text: Where do I look to - where do I spot trends?

1256.text: I was at Starbucks today and I was sitting next to very interesting

1260.text: Millennial having a conversation about her job at Salesforce and

1264.text: her co-workers and I wish I could have taped that conversation.

1267.text: I was fascinated by how quick it was happening

1270.text: and what she was talking about.

1272.text: And so I travel quite a bit, I travel outside the U.S

1275.text: quite a bit, but I don't believe that great

1278.text: trends are started in New York and LA.

1282.text: I think that, especially today, trends come from all over the place.

1289.text: And I'm really fascinated by people,

1292.text: and I think that to think that you can go to one place and

1296.text: one source and get everything you need is very antiquated.

1300.text: There was a time when people would produce a trend report and send

1304.text: it out and say to everybody these are the colors of the season.

1307.text: And I think going back to the technology piece,

1311.text: consumers are - it's so fascinating to me.

1315.text: Think about when fashion blogging became a thing, right.

1319.text: So think about a magazine like Lucky that when you open Lucky today

1322.text: I feel like fashion bloggers drive that book where years ago it was

1327.text: editors dictating to us what was cool and what was edgy and now we

1330.text: look at really cool people and those are who - I think Olivia Palermo

1335.text: probably tells more people what's cool than a fashion editor.

1338.text: And so it's interesting to see that power play where

1341.text: now it's like we all have to work together.

1343.text: And so for me commuting is a great time.

1348.text: I can always tell when a trend is massed

1353.text: based on my time in the airport.

1354.text: I'll give you an example of two: Uggs and Toms.

1358.text: When you get on a plane and everybody walking past you no

1361.text: matter what age is engaged with a certain type of brand,

1364.text: that's when you can start to see mass influence and there

1366.text: are times where I remember seeing two people at an airport

1370.text: with Toms and then I remember every other person having

1373.text: a pair of Toms and so I'm always looking at that moment,

1376.text: that breaker moment when something is really becoming mass.

1380.text: We had a trend a couple of years ago, we called massclusivity,

1382.text: which is the idea that everybody wants mass

1385.text: products that are customized for them,

1390.text: So I don't think that trends come from

1395.text: just one place or just one person,

1397.text: because at the end of the day my clients want volume and so we're

1403.text: right now creating something called the Millennial brand index

1406.text: where we're ranking brands in many different categories.

1408.text: And I'm talking to someone who is going to be part of a judging

1412.text: panel for this project and she said to me you're talking about

1416.text: all these companies that are really interesting.

1417.text: Of course the ones that I like,

1418.text: like Warby Parker - I love Warby Parker.

1420.text: She said what I want to know is if the

1423.text: girl in Kansas loves Warby Parker.

1425.text: And I think that is a great question because we sometimes

1428.text: can become a little obsessed with what's happening on the Coast

1431.text: and we don't realize it's a huge company - a company - huge

1434.text: country with so many different opinions and so I try to not

1439.text: let one idea dictate when I think something is cool.

1443.text: And I also don't think that I had the answers.

1446.text: I think you find a lot of people,

1448.text: I don't know if you guys experience this,

1450.text: I see it a lot in business where it's

1451.text: like because I have a child who is 12,

1453.text: I understand all 12 year-olds or I know Millennials,

1458.text: And what I - I always take the approach is that I don't know anything

1462.text: and that I think everyday something is changing and everyday

1466.text: I'm getting new access to new research and information,

1469.text: and so I always try to approach it from I'm just here to learn and to

1472.text: observe and to interpret and I don't really have an end goal from it.

1476.text: I just want to know what's interesting.

2379.text: I walk into a room, I know that if I

2391.text: and to go to a place where none of those things are certain and to see

2395.text: people still work so hard and come up with unbelievable solutions.

2400.text: I was on a remote island called Bussi Island and met an entrepreneur

2404.text: who had developed a solar backpack that basically lit this clinic where

2410.text: women would have to go if they could get there to give birth.

2413.text: And when - if they happened to give birth at night, there was no light.

2417.text: So babies were born and the first thing

2420.text: this baby is doing is inhaling smoke.

2422.text: And so, we don't think about those things,

2425.text: about the impact of those things and to see an entrepreneur -

2428.text: they came up with a solar backpack,

2429.text: now there is lighting, simple solutions.

2432.text: And so I think so many of us spend so much time thinking

2436.text: about very complex things and to see entrepreneurs

2439.text: focus on things that might seem so simple,

2940.text: We go in just because we like it and it's interesting.

2943.text: So I don't necessarily think that we have to - we are also

2946.text: in a place where we're like saying this is bad and that

2949.text: is bad and I think as consumers we have to say,

2952.text: I like this, so I'm going to do it or I'm interested in this,

2955.text: so I'm going to eat this.

2956.text: It doesn't mean I'm going eat fast-food everyday.

2959.text: But if I want to go have a burger,

2960.text: I'm going to have a burger and that's fine.

2961.text: And I think that's what I appreciate about

2964.text: Millennials is the idea of like it's fine.

2966.text: If I want to eat at Chipotle three days a week,

2969.text: that's actually cool and it's fine.

2970.text: And so I kind of like that approach to things.

2974.text: Can I ask you a question about gender and

2978.text: I mean, is it ... Interesting question. ...

2981.text: So is being female an issue with whatever you want to pursue,

2984.text: is being black an issue with whatever you want to pursue?

2986.text: And is it an issue, is it a liability, is it an asset?

2990.text: What's your read and take both objectively and personally?

2995.text: I was asked that question when I got older and I didn't get it.

3000.text: And I said, at least speaking from my personal career,

3003.text: I came up at a time in '96 before Backstreet Boys and Britney

3008.text: Spears and Elle Girl and Teen Vogue and Teen People and

3011.text: I kind of rode into the teen wave and I happened to be a

3014.text: person who just had more insights than anyone else.

3016.text: And so I'm a big believer that,

3019.text: at least for me, the only color people saw

3020.text: was green and my ability to make money.

3023.text: like the only color people saw with me is green.

3028.text: I think that this is one of our trends again for next year,

3032.text: we're talking about this Power Girl trend

3034.text: and I'm a little put off personally,

3037.text: it's probably the most controversial thing I'm going to say today,

3040.text: by people who think they need to tell girls

3043.text: that they can run as fast as boys today.

3045.text: I have a niece who is five, I never want her to hear that.

3049.text: I want to know - I want her to know to run fast.

3052.text: She's growing up - my sister is a sociology professor,

3056.text: she thinks her grandma is awesome, her aunt runs a company,

3060.text: Phoebe already knows she can do whatever

3061.text: she wants to do with her life.

3062.text: And so I'm a little put off by that older - and again even my journey,

3067.text: right, that would like me saying guys entrepreneurship is so hard.

3071.text: You don't know what it's like the last 18 years.

3073.text: Like my world, my journey is very different.

3076.text: I couldn't build a website for less than $1,000,

3079.text: get business cards for less than $35 and have a business

3082.text: up and running via LegalZoom in two days.

3085.text: That's an opportunity you have and I think I have to respect that.

3090.text: And so I'm a little put off by campaigns where

3093.text: it's like girls are just as good as boys.

3095.text: It's like I don't need a campaign to say that.

3098.text: And it's hard because I think that -- are there inequalities that exist?

3104.text: But also I can't truly speak to that because I've always created

3106.text: my own job and my own opportunity and so I will say one of the

3110.text: things that made me really love Dell was they talked about empowering

3115.text: women and every time I was in a meeting there,

3117.text: there were woman running the show in a way

3121.text: and really empowered within that company,

3122.text: and so it was great to feel like I wasn't just saying something

3125.text: and then sitting in a room with all men dictating and so that's

3128.text: important to see that if you're promoting a company culture that

3131.text: you're living it and I very much felt that they were.

3134.text: But yes, I have a problem with - I think girl power is the

3139.text: issue of the day and so people have decided that...

3142.text: And there are a lot of trends we can

3144.text: speak to in politics that we can see,

3146.text: we're trending toward this movement and so I think

3150.text: that Millennials see through all of that.

3154.text: I just think that pandering - it's like oh,

3157.text: now we're going to talk about girls and how awesome girls are.

3160.text: I think that toys for girls and things like that - I didn't have

3166.text: a course in school that was like this is math for girls.

3170.text: I took advanced math and science classes from

3174.text: middle school until I graduated at college.

3176.text: So ... And it didn't even go through your mind that that was an issue?

3181.text: Or that girls were - my girlfriends were

3182.text: like sitting next to me in classes.

3183.text: This is what we did and so I have a problem when

3186.text: we kind of call that out as like hey you,

3189.text: Like that's kind of like okay.

3193.text: We have time for one final question.

3197.text: Any - yes, we got one right there, back there.

3200.text: Based on what you just said,

3201.text: do you think that being like a good sociologist is kind of an essential

3204.text: part of market research and like how have you gained those skills?

3212.text: Sorry, do I think that being a good sociologist

3214.text: is an important part of my job?

3217.text: I, in general, I tend not to hire marketing

3221.text: people to work for my company.

3223.text: I tend to hire people who come from some sort of social science,

3227.text: because I think what's really important is in marketing sometimes

3231.text: we're taught to create the voice of the consumer and I feel

3234.text: like we're living in a time now where we have to actually

3237.text: interpret what the consumer is saying to us and create for

3241.text: consumers what they're looking for from us.

3243.text: And so I also think it's a very European style of marketing,

3246.text: where they really spend a lot of time

3250.text: okay, we now have these consumer segments and now we're going to

3253.text: create these products to satisfy that and I've seen that through -

3257.text: I've had some people work for my agency from Europe and that was

3260.text: very much the way they came into the experience versus I have the

3263.text: best new car idea and now how are we going to sell it?

3268.text: And so I think that I look for people that bring those kind of skills

3273.text: to the table because we really are in a time where technology is

3276.text: really creating - I keep talking about this democracy where consumers

3281.text: can tell us instantly and it's ever happened before.

3285.text: I use this example, when I was a teenager if I wanted

3287.text: to know if Jane Cosmetics tested on animals,

3289.text: I'd call an 800 number on the back of the package,

3293.text: I'd ask a question and then go with what they told me.

3296.text: Right now if you want to know that,

3297.text: you can find out in a minute or less.

3299.text: And if you don't like what you see,

3300.text: you can start a petition on change.org.

3302.text: And so what consumers can do and how quickly and instantly you

3306.text: can do it I think has totally changed what we as marketers do.

3311.text: And so I really look for people who - cultural anthropologists;

3316.text: really interested in what people want and not

3319.text: interested in coming in with absolute outcome.
